For our numbers (m = 2, α = 0.1) this becomes

That is, for the temporal network, if you choose a recovery rate γ then the transmission probability β must be set equal to (R₀ γ)/(2 m α) in order to have R₀ = 3.

In many cases one “aggregates” the time–varying contacts over a time window (for example, over one typical infectious period, T = 1/γ) so that one obtains a static network. In this static (or “integrated”) network an edge between two nodes exists if they have been in contact at least once during T; in some cases one keeps also a weight w that is proportional to the number (or frequency) of contacts.   w = 2 m α (T) / N = 2 m α/(γ N),
since each ordered pair i→j has a contact rate ≈ (m α)/N and there are two “directions.”

  π = 1 – exp[– (2mα)/(N γ)].

One then “lumps” the epidemiological transmission into an effective “transmissibility” along an edge. If in any given contact an infection occurs with probability β, then multiple independent contacts will yield an overall transmission probability along the edge
  T_edge = 1 – (1 – β)^(# of contacts).

When contacts occur according to a Poisson process the overall transmissibility along the aggregated edge is
  T_edge = 1 − exp[– β · (expected number of contacts)].
If we imagine that the weight of the edge is now “large” (obtained by aggregating many time steps) one can write, approximately,
  T_edge = 1 – exp[– β · w*],
where w* is an “integrated contact‐intensity” between the two nodes. A common (and simple) choice is to take
  w* = 2 m α/γ,
which is the expected number of contacts an arbitrary node experiences (either by being active or being contacted) during its infectious period (note that in the temporal network we “saw” that the total contact rate is 2 m α). Then the effective probability of transmission along an edge in the time–aggregated network is

  T_edge = 1 – exp[– (2 m α β)/γ].

Now, if the aggregated (unweighted) network is homogeneous (i.e. nearly “regular”), then a common mean–field estimate for the reproduction number is

  R₀(static) = T_edge × ⟨k⟩,
where ⟨k⟩ is the average degree of the aggregated network. If one constructs the aggregated network by “linking” any pair that had at least one contact over T, then one finds
  ⟨k⟩ ≃ (N – 1) π ≃ N [1 – exp(– (2 m α)/(Nγ))].
For N large and (2 m α)/(Nγ) small, one may approximate
  ⟨k⟩ ≃ 2 m α/γ,
which is exactly the total number of distinct contacts per individual in time T.

Thus one obtains
  R₀(static) = [1 – exp(– (2 m α β)/γ)] × (2 m α/γ).

Now if we wish this R₀ (static) to be 3 we must have

  [1 – exp(– (2 m α β)/γ)] · (2 m α/γ) = 3.

That is, the mapping from β to R₀ in the static (aggregated) case is given by

  R₀(static) = (2 m α/γ) [1 – exp(– (2 m α β)/γ)],
or, equivalently, one may “calibrate” β by solving
  1 – exp(– (2 m α β)/γ) = (R₀(static)γ)/(2mα).

  β = – (γ/(2 m α)) ln [1 – (R₀(static)γ)/(2 m α)].

  β = – (γ/(0.4)) ln [1 – (3γ)/(0.4)]     (so long as (3γ)/(0.4) < 1).

Note that (as often happens) the mapping for the static network is nonlinear in β because several contacts can occur along the same edge.
